name: TheAtlantic
text: "The independence of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority is affirmed, while still granting the president the outcome he desired," @AdamSerwer writes: https://t.co/zRkQWGvS8O

name: TheAtlantic
text:
Alabama Democrat Doug Jones knows that the fight for civil rights is a long one. But he's optimistic about the future, he tells @IsaacDovere.
https://t.co/awR9D0DlSj

name: TheAtlantic
text: Like the one-child policy, Beijing’s repressive actions against minority Uighur Muslims are about preserving power. As @meifongwriter writes, China's birth-control policies were always less about births, more about control. https://t.co/Ngq5lnbH5O

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Simply giving people cash turns out to be a powerful way to protect workers during a public-health crisis, to alleviate poverty, and to empower employees to bargain with employers. Uncle Sam needs to give out a lot more," @AnnieLowrey writes: https://t.co/W04l38hEpg

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The more significant effect of Mazars and Vance was always going to be on the level of institutions rather than individuals—the positioning of the presidency in relation to Congress and state law enforcement," @qjurecic writes: https://t.co/dRQsDGPT5R

name: TheAtlantic
text: As another week closes, America isn’t any closer to regaining control over this outbreak. Let’s recap four things we learned while reporting on the pandemic. The latest Atlantic Daily, by @mimbsy: https://t.co/Y70vN0nNjv

name: TheAtlantic
text: That the president’s reprieve for his friend Roger Stone was predictable makes it no less brazen, writes @RussellBerman: https://t.co/uOhSgNfwVV

name: TheAtlantic
text: Donald Trump, the man, lost at the Supreme Court. But Donald Trump, the candidate, can claim victory. Our writers explain in the latest Atlantic Daily: https://t.co/jN9nmtoMzY
